texts.en: Mrs. Odigie C. J. is 47 years old and a trained patient medicine dealer in a suburb of Edo State, Nigeria. She request for the above amount to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sale

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: I changed to this business six (6) years ago and I have no cause to regret it. Though I am 31 years old; my numerous customers always give me satisfactions, says Mrs. Felicia O.. She needs the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is a 25-year-old man who has a small welding shop in Kirkuk. This is his first loan from AL-Aman, and he has applied to get $1000 to purchase a new welding machine. He lives with his family and is responsible for them. He will be married in the next couple of months.

This man is very active. He works 12-hour days. With the loan, he is looking to increase his income and buy more assets for the shop.

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new welding machine

loans.name: Franca

texts.en: Mrs. Franca U., a 32-year-old dynamic client of LAPO. She has proved her worth of experience in her line of business. She is maintaining her repayment schedule with LAPO without fail. She needs this money ($400) to keep her business booming.

loans.use: To buy more baby wears for sale

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: A trained fashion designer. Mrs. Rose O., a 55 years old dedicated woman and a leader of one LAPO groups in Nigeria. She has 10 years experience in fashion design. She is looking forward to having the above amount for her business growth.

loans.use:
To buy more sewing machines and
materials

loans.name: Juliana

texts.en: A 40 years woman who works so hard to take care of the family. She started her garri business 8 years ago. She joined LAPO two years ago after starting her business with her little saving. According to her, LAPO came to rescue her when her business was at the point of collapsing as a result of inadequate running capital. She is eager to get the above amount for her business growth.

loans.use: To buy more bags of garri for sale

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: A 48 years old, Mrs. Esther A.  specializes on sales of shoes and bags since 2000. A business she learnt for 2 years. She plans to improve her business with the above amount.

loans.use: To buy more shoes and bags for sale

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Mrs. Stella A. has done this work for years. She said that LAPO has lifted her up from the grip of poverty. She hails from Ubiaja of Edo State, Nigeria; married with three children and she hope of getting the above loan for business expansion.

loans.use:
To buy more material for soda
making

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: A foodstuffs seller. Mrs. Grace I. lives in a semi-urban area in Nigeria and is a dedicated and credit-worthy poor woman. She plays major roles in her family up-keeping and proud to be a LAPO client, because LAPO made her what she is today. She needs the above amount for her business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
This entrepreneur is 24 years old. He lives with his big family in the south of Kirkuk. He has six brothers. He is only worker in the house. He has a copy shop in the market. He also has one computer in his shop. He is looking forward to receiving a loan from AL-Aman to purchase a new computer, new scanner, and new printer.

He wants to enhance his standard of living and increase his income .

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new computer, scanner, and printer

loans.name: Felicia

texts.en: Mrs. Felicia I. is 36 years old. She is a specialist in sales of foodstuffs, a business she learnted from her mother. She has proved her credit worthiness for the past two (2) years she has been benefiting from LAPO loan. She needs the above amount to improve her business.

loans.use:
To buy drinks to sell and 
 ingredients for pepper soup

loans.name: Emilio

texts.en:
Emilio is a craftsperson working in leather and faux leather. He makes belts for men and women, working with his wife who takes care of the sales, and his child, who takes care of the design of their products. This is the source of income that allows him to support his three children who are dependent on him.

The workshop is located in Zona de Rio Seco del El Alto. The product is sold in the cities of La Paz, Cochamba, and Santa Cruz.

The credit will be used for the purchase of raw material (leather and faux leather), to meet the market demand.

This is his second credit with IMPRO. The first loan was paid on time and his good qualifications allow him to access another loan and increase his family income.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

Emilio es artesano en cuero y cuerina, realiza cinturones para caballeros y damas, trabaja con su esposa quien se encarga de la comercialización, y su hijo se encarga del diseño de sus productos. Esta es su fuente de ingreso que le permite la manutención de sus tres hijos que dependen de él. El taller esta ubicado en el mismo domicilio Zona de Rió Seco del El Alto; el producto es comercializado en las ciudades de La Paz, Cochabamba y Santa Cruz. El crédito lo destinara para la compra de materia prima (cuero y cuerina), para satisfacer la cantidad de demanda que tiene en su mercado. Es el segundo crédito con Impro; el primer préstamo fue pagado puntualmente y su buena calificación le permite acceder a otro préstamo e incrementar sus ingresos familiares.

loans.use: Compra de cuero y cuerina

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Mrs. Stella A. has worked on her shop for years. She said that LAPO has lifted her up from the grip of poverty. She hails from Ubiaja of Edo State, Nigeria. She is married with three children and hopes to get the above loan for business expansion.

loans.use:
To buy more material for soda
making

loans.name: Alimatu

texts.en: Mrs. Alimatu A. is 40 years old. She is a specialist in sales of foodstuffs, a business she learned from her mother. She is married with six children and needs the above amount for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more food items

loans.name: Yadira

texts.en:
Yadira is a decorator for social events such as birthday parties, weddings and baptisms. She makes most of the decorations herself with skills she has learned. She has been doing this for about 7 years and is doing very well. She has no shortage of clients because her work is well liked. She works with her mother as an assistant.

Yadira will use the money from this loan to invest in supplies for her decorations. She has already borrowed from Mifex before and she invested the money in new and creative decorations. She was able to improve the quality of her work and thus increased her popularity. She also teaches local children how to make balloon decorations at the Mifex Merit Centers. Yadira admits that the business has been her crutch over the last year. Her husband left her and her two children and this business has not only provided financial stability but also helps Yadira stay positive and happy. She thanks the lenders from Kiva for their great support of entrepreneurs.

loans.use: to invest in Materials

loans.name: Christo

texts.en: Christo O. is a young woman of 37 years. She is married with three (3) children, a LAPO client for over 6 years. She has proved her wealth of experience in her line of business. She needs the money ($550) to keep her business booming.

loans.use: To buy more ice cream ingredients

loans.name: Sonia

texts.en: Sonia has a small market where she sells school and office supplies, as well as other items. She started off just selling basic supplies but now also sells off-the-shelf food items and beverages. She is seeking a loan in order to invest in inventory for her business and increase her product diversity. She hopes that with this loan she will be able to save enough to make improvements to her home over the next year. She has two daughters, who are in school at the moment. Her husband is a handyman who supports his family and works very hard.

loans.use: to improve her inventory

loans.name: Maris

texts.en: "Cooked food is a quick turnover business," says Maris A.,  a 30-year-old woman. She is eager to get more money to buy foodstuffs in order to meet her customers' demands.

loans.use: To buy more food ingredients

loans.name: Grace

texts.en: Grace E. is a young woman of 38 years. She hails from Uromi of Edo State, Nigeria has three (3) children, and has been a LAPO client for over 7 years; she had proved her worth of experience in her line of business. She needs the money ($650) to keep her business booming.

loans.use: To buy more food items to sell

loans.name: Clara

texts.en: Mrs. Clara I. is 40 years old, married with five (5) children. She learned the business from her mother and she started her own business in 1985. The above amount is to help her improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: Mrs. Stella A. has a supermarket where she sells all kinds of things. She is 33 years old and married with a child. She hails from Uromi of Edo State, Nigeria. She wish for the above loan for her business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more provisions  to sell.

loans.name: Esther

texts.en: A woman of 36 years old, married with eight (8) children, she lives in a semi-urban area of Benin City, Edo State of Nigeria. She started her business in the year 1985. She specializes in the sales of food items. According to her, the above amount will be a good help to her in order to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions to sell.

loans.name: Samuel

texts.en: Mr. Samuel I. hails from Uromi of Edo State, Nigeria. He specializes in making shoes for the public. He is 25 years old, married with two (2) children. He is requesting the above amount for business expansion

loans.use: To buy more materials

loans.name: Pius

texts.en: A dedicated client of LAPO who specializes in the sales of wood, Pius A. hails from Uromi of Edo State, Nigeria. He wishes that the above amount specified come to him for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more woods for sale

loans.name: Clara

texts.en: Mrs. Clara E. lives in Uromi, Edo State of Nigeria. 31 years old and married with one (1) child, she started her business in the year 1997. She needs the above amount for her business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more clothing for sale

loans.name: Rosemary

texts.en: A dedicated client of LAPO who specializes in the sale of palm cannel to her community, Rosemary O. hails from Uromi in Edo State, Nigeria. She wishes that the above amount specified come to her for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more palm cannel for sale

loans.name: Anna

texts.en: Mrs. Ann B. lives in the urban area of Uromi, Edo State, Nigeria. She learned her trade business for 6 years before she opened her own shop. She is happily married with a child (1). She needs the above amount for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more crates of drinks

loans.name: Adedara

texts.en: Mrs. Adedara V. is a cook. She is happily married with five (5) children; she is from the semi-urban area of Jattu, Edo State, Nigeria. She hopes to get the above amount to enable her to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: Mrs. Victoria S. is 24 years old. She learned her hair-dressing service for 3 years. She wishes that the above amount come to her for business expansion

loans.use: To buy more hair-dressing equipment

loans.name: Anthonia

texts.en: Mrs. Anthonia F. is 40 years old. She sells provisions to her community. She wishes that the above amount come to her for business expansion.

loans.use: To buy more provisions

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en: A married mother of six (6) children Mrs. Josephine A. is a trader and lives, in Jattu, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells cooked food and drinks to the public. She is looking forward to getting this loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more crates of drinks

loans.name: Aishetu

texts.en: A mother of seven (7) children Mrs. Aishetu A., a trader, lives in Jattu, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells used clothes to the community. She is looking forward to getting this loan to improve her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Goodness

texts.en: I changed to this business five (5) years ago and I have no cause to regret it. Though I am 46 years old, my numerous customers always give me satisfaction, says Mrs. Goodness E.. She needs the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for sale

loans.name: Christian

texts.en: I have no cause to regret being a LAPO client. She is 45-years-old and married with eight (8) children. My numerous customers always give me satisfaction, says Mrs. Christian O.. She needs the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Rebecca

texts.en: A beautiful woman who has no cause to regret that she belong to LAPO. She is 38-years-old and married with four (4) children. My numerous customers always give me satisfaction, says Mrs. Rebecca O.. She needs the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more shoes  for sale

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en: Mrs. Comfort E., a 40-year-old woman, sells foodstuff to people. She is married with two (2) children. She is proud of her business and promise to effectively use the above amount to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuffs for sale

loans.name: Angela

texts.en: A trader who sells provisions to people. She is married with two (2) children. She is proud of her business and promises to effectively use the above amount to expand her business above all is 56 years old.

loans.use: To buy more provisions for sale

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en: Mrs. Eunice M. is 34-years-young and married with five (5) children. She hails from Jattu in Edo State, Nigeria. She is a well-trained nurse. She is requesting the above amount to increase her business.

loans.use: To buy more drugs for sale

loans.name: Victoria

texts.en: I am proud to be LAPO Client say Mrs. Victoria O., a 50-year-old woman, is from the semi-urban area of Jattu, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells drinks to people in her environment and is married with six (6) children. She needs the above loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more crates of drinks for sale

loans.name: Roseline

texts.en: Mrs. Roseline I., a 56-year- old woman, is from the semi-urban area of Jattu, Edo State, Nigeria. She sells chicken to people in her environment and is married with three (3) children. She needs the above loan to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more chickens for sale

loans.name: Daniel

texts.en:
“I would like to make a garage for my car as I can no longer leave it outside of my house. It has been hit numerous times on the street, and it has cost me a lot of work to repair it. I also want to be able to use it to get to work. Also, I would like to make a curb on this street as it often floods and the water collects in a pool on my land"

Daniel is requesting a loan of $ 800.00 dollars to make a garage and a burn next to his house.

loans.use: Install a garage and raise the curb next to my house

loans.name: Stella

texts.en: I started this business years ago and it has helped me take care of my family. I know how to safeguard my capital to ensure continuity in business. All these are words of Mrs. Stella E., married with eight (8) children. She is requesting $400 to expand her business.

loans.use: To buy more baby things for sale

loans.name: Musili

texts.en: Mrs. Musili O. A., a 47-year-old woman living in a semi-rural area in Jattu, Edo State of Nigeria, sells female wrappers for a living. She is married with six (6) children. She hopes for the above amount for the expansion of her clothing business.

loans.use: To buy more wrappers for sale

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en:
"The security of my family concerns me greatly, since in the neighborhood where we live there also many gang members and many robberies. I would like to put up bars around my house before they can get in or something unfortunate happens." I am requesting $1000 for the installation of bars on my home.

Translated from Spanish by a Kiva volunteer.

“Me preocupa mucho la seguridad de mi familia ya que en la colonia en donde vivimos habitan también muchos pandilleros y hay muchos robos, me gustaría poner rejas alrededor de mi casa antes de que se puedan meter o suceda algo lamentable”. Solicito 1,000.00 dlls para la instalación de rejas en mi casa.

loans.use: Install bars on my home

loans.name: Benjamin

texts.en:
"I've had my business for 1 year, selling tacos and barbecue. It's going well for me, since I'm on a street where there are many points of sale in garages, but I would like to buy a truck that will be sold to me for a cheap price, since it's run down. It will work very well for me to take it to another point in the city and to increase my sales that way." I am requesting R1200 to purchase a truck.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

“Tengo mi negocio desde hace 1 año, vendo tacos de barbacoa y me va bien ya que estoy en una calle en donde se ponen muchos puestos en venta de garaje; pero gustaría comprar un camión que me venden barato debido a que esta descompuesto pero a mi me serviría mucho para ponerlo en otro punto de la ciudad y así aumentar mis ventas”. Solicito $ 1,200.00 dlls para compra un camión.

loans.use: Buy a truck to open another taco business

loans.name: Faamati

texts.en: Faamati is a forty year old mother of four children.  She runs a stall at the local flea market where she sells the produce from her small farm.  Faamati admits that it is difficult to raise children on your own as well as running a business at the same time, because that determines whether your family eats or not.  Faamati is concerned because she knows that not all of her crops are growing to their full potential and are being over-run by local insects.  In order to ensure that she is able to provide the basic necessities for her children, Faamati is searching for a way to improve her crop yield, and thus has applied for a small loan to buy some fertilizers and pest control agents for furher development of her business.

loans.use: Fertilizers and pest control agents

loans.name: Agnes

texts.en: Agnes joined SPBD nearly a year ago and has been very active in her Center’s meetings and activities.  She and her husband design and make jewelry and sell their product at the local market to tourists and locals.  While her husband does much of the designing and crafting, Agnes’ specialty is pricing and sales.  Agnes says that her first loan really helped her increase the quantity of the product she was able to supply to the market, and thus she was able to increase her revenues.  With her strong history of repayment, she qualifies for an additional loan and will use the funds to purchase some additional equipment (x-saws) and raw materials (earring hooks and paints) to be able to expand her supply further.

loans.use: Buy raw materials (earring hooks and paints) and equipment (x-saws)

loans.name: Me

texts.en: Me is a thirty-six year old woman and is happily married.  She has three children. In order to support her family financially, Me’s husband works at his small plantation while Me runs a small shop in front of her house where she supplies basic household items and snacks to the local villagers.  Profits from Me’s shop have had to be used to buy basic tools and seeds for her husband’s plantation, so Me sometimes relies on micro-loan facilities to be able to finance an inventory purchase.  With a strong history of repayment in full, Me is again applying for a small loan to re-stock her shop so that she can maintain a consistent supply for the local villagers.

loans.use: Buy merchandise to re-stock her shop

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: Miss Thuy and her husband are the same of 29 ages. They have a child who is going to school in grade 2. They don’t have any land for cultivation. Mr Khang works as a daily laborer but the work is not stable. Miss Thuy rented a hut to sell food at her village. They borrowed a loan with no interest from the project, which has been important for them, as it increased their income by about $5/person/month. Average income is $14/person/month. Before, Miss Thuy borrowed money with interest of 6% from lender. Miss Thuy has repaid a loan of $75, and now she asks to borrow a loan of $75 again.

loans.use: sell food

loans.name: Pablo

texts.en:
Pablo is 62 years old, married, and has 2 children. He is a commercial salesman. He sells all kind of daily consumables. He started with a small amount of money that he used to stock his business, 15 years ago.

He has been in business for more than 15 years. Thanks to his work he has been able to send his children to school and pay for his basic needs. He also gets help from his wife, who mans the store and sells office supplies and photocopies.

He wants to open a boutique at his house, to sell ladies and mens clothing, which will allow him to augment his sales. Later, he plans to expand the space of his store to create a showroom.

Translated from Spanish by Ramón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer.

Pablo tiene 62 años, está casado y tiene 2 hijos. Su actividad, es comerciante (despensa). El vende todo tipo de productos de consumo diario. Empezo con un pequeño capital con el que surtio su negocio hace ya 15 años atras. Está dedicado al oficio hace más de 15 años, gracias a su trabajo pudo educar a sus hijos y cubrir sus necesidades básicas. Tambien recibe la ayuda de su esposa, quien atiende el negocio y realiza venta de productos de libreria y fotocopias. Tiene proyectado abrir en su domicilio una boutique, venta de ropas para damas y caballeros, lo cual le permitirá aumentar sus ventas Mas adelante planea ampliar su espacio físico para exponer sus productos.

loans.use: To acquire oil, flour, pasta, rice, sugar, and other things to sell

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: Miss Thuy is 37 and her husband is 43 years old. They have 5 children between 17 and 2 who are going to school. They don’t have any land for cultivation. Mr Thao, her husband is a mason but he can only find work in the dry season. Miss Thuy sells vegetable and fruits at the small market. Her selling is thus important to increase her family about $1.5/person/month. Their income is $9/person/month. Miss Thuy has already repaid the first loan in time. Now, she wants to borrow a loan of $75 for her selling business.

loans.use: sells vegetable and fruits

loans.name: Ramona

texts.en: Ramona is a fifty-seven year old woman. She is married and has seven children.  Ramona has long been the breadwinner of the family and even her grown children continue to rely on her for financial support.  She operates a small shop in her village, but prior to joining SPBD she was never able to keep more than a couple of items in stock.  She was anxious to join in order to have access to micro-loan facilities that she could use to finance inventory purchases as needed.  This strategy has been successful, and Ramona has been able to expand her product line to include women’s and girls' clothing.  Ramona is justifiably proud of her role in the family as the income-earner.  Providing Ramona with further credit allows her to maintain this title and continue to incrementally expand her shop for the benefit of her family.

loans.use: Merchandise for re-sale in her shop

loans.name: Olga

texts.en:
Olga is 26 years old, single, and doesn't have any children. She is a university student. She inherited her business and knowledge about crafts from her mother. Her suppliers are from the city of Areguá, where she is able to obtain merchandise at a lot lower cost and where she can place advance orders. Her business is located in one of the neighborhoods with most commercial activity in the city of Caacupé, especially during the weekend, where there are lots of visitors.

She wants to take better advantage of the location of her business, by diversifying her products and services. She wants to expand by offering drinks and food, selling clothing, and other goods.

Translated from Spanish by Ramón F. Kolb, Kiva Volunteer.

Olga tiene 26 años, es soltera y no tiene hijos. Ella es estudiante universitaria. El negocio y sus conocimientos sobre la artesanía lo heredo de su madre. Sus proveedores son de la ciudad de Areguá, donde consigue mercaderia a un precio mucho menor y los pedidos los realiza con mucha anticipación. Su negocio está ubicado en una de las zonas de mayor movimiento comercial de la ciudad de Caacupé, especialmente los fines de semana donde se registra el mayor movimiento de visitantes.

Tiene proyectado sacarle mayor provecho a la ubicación que posee su negocio, con la diversificación de sus productos y servicios, ya que lo quiere ampliar con la incorporación de la venta de bebidas y comidas, e inclusive con la venta de ropas y otros artículos.

loans.use: To buy ceramic crafts

loans.name: Foai

texts.en: Foai is a married woman with seven children.  Her husband works as a teacher at the local primary school, but with seven children, these wages are not enough to put food on the table and keep all the children in school.  In order to supplement this income and ensure her children can remain in school, Foai applied for an initial SPBD loan to launch a small grocery store.  She stocks basic staples like flour, sugar and spices.  Having repaid her initial loan in full and on time, Foai is anxious to secure additional loan funds to support an expansion of her product line.  She believes this will result in enhanced profit and bring in the income that her large family needs.

loans.use: Purchase stock for her store

loans.name: Lalotoa

texts.en: Lalotoa has a history of using micro-loan facilities to make incremental upgrades to her small village store.  She has used two previous loans to make renovations and to finance an expansion in product line and inventories.  She is passionate about being a successful businesswoman, and she spends the bulk of her time operating and finding ways to improve her business.  She is now seeking a third loan that she will use to again increase her inventory, aiming to provide a consistent supply to the local villagers.

loans.use: Purchase food and merchandise for re-sale

loans.name: Kalameli

texts.en: Kalameli is 34 years old and has five daughters.  She lives in a small Samoan village with her daughters and husband.  Kalameli’s husband is unemployed, so Kalameli is the breadwinner, and it is the income from her mat sales that supports their large family.  Kalameli weaves mats and fans according to the traditional Samoan art.  She is anxious to secure loan funds so that she can rent out a flea market stall in her village from which she can sell her mats and fans.  Currently, she has to transport them to the city for sale, and this is a costly exercise that eats into her margin.  Kalameli is certain that there is enough local demand for her product if she can secure a stall at the nearby market.

loans.use: Flea market rent

loans.name: Lauiula

texts.en: Lauiula is a 41-year old woman with four children.  Her husband works as a farmer and is able to earn ST 200 (USD 80) per week from selling his taro and banana crops.  When Lauiula heard about SPBD from a friend, she joined because she was certain that with access to capital she could greatly increase her family’s income.  Lauiula used initial loans to re-stock her parent’s old village store that was no longer in operation.  She re-opened it and now with the upgrades she was able to do, she can bring in up to ST 700 a week (approximately USD 280).  With access to loan funds, Lauiula has more than quadrupled her family’s income.  With this track record, she is certainly an SPBD success story.  Much of Lauiula’s recent profit has been reinvested in her husband’s business so that the plantation can be upgraded and the income potential of their land increased.  Lauiula is seeking an additional SPBD loan in order to finance another inventory purchase for her shop.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her store

loans.name: Maria

texts.en: Maria is 49 years old and the mother of two grown sons.  Her sons migrated overseas in order to find employment opportunities.  Both have their own families to look after, and Maria and her husband work hard to support themselves and not rely on their children for financial support.  They operate a vegetable farm and Maria’s access to micro-loan facilities have helped them upgrade their farm with better equipment and fertilizers.  They sell their crop at the local market.  Having repaid previous loan funds in full and on time, Maria is seeking an additional loan specifically to expand the variety of vegetables they grow and purchase some fertilizer to enhance their yield.

loans.use: Buy vegetable seeds, fertilizers, pest control agents

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en: Caroline S. is a thirty-eight year old married mother of three.  Her business is sewing, and she specializes in making popular Samoan styles of men’s shirts (Aloa) and ladies’ dresses (Puletasi).  Her domestic duties allow her to sew four days a week, and she can fill the orders of five to eight customers each day.  Working at this pace, she can make sales of about ST 200 (USD 80) each working day.  Caroline used an initial SPBD loan to launch her business by purchasing a sewing machine.  Having repaid this loan and established a good customer base, she is now seeking a second loan.  With this loan she will begin purchasing her own material rather than asking her customers to supply it for her to fulfill their orders.  She thinks this will greatly improve her customer service and expects that she can further increase her customer base this way.

loans.use: Purchase material and set of sewing tools.

loans.name: Iokapeta

texts.en: Iokapeta is a 46-year old mother, married with 7 children. Her 5 older children have successfully finished school and are now working.  Her two youngest children are still in school.  Iokapeta is justifiably very proud of having provided an education for her oldest children, and she is determined to keep the younger two in school as well.  She admits that all this wouldn’t have been possible without the income from her banana plantation.  She has used SPBD loans to build up this plantation to where it is today, providing a steady income, and thus a means to making real improvements in the family’s standard of living.  She has used four previous SPBD loans to achieve this and having repaid these loans in full and on time, she is eligible for a fifth loan that she will use for making some much-needed repairs to her home.

loans.use: Home repairs

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is a single female of 22 years old.  She lives in the small Samoan village of Moamoa.  Mary says that she wasn’t a very good student while in school.  And so rather than continue, she asked her mother if she could attend sewing courses.  She went to these courses for two and a half years.  And although she didn’t complete her full course, she felt comfortable that she had built up the skills and knowledge necessary to start her own sewing business.  She admits that since then she has learned a lot from experience.  She joined SPBD to get started and with her first loan, she purchased a sewing machine.  She is now requesting a second loan that she will use to buy materials for her sewing.  Mary’s ultimate goal is to become a professional tailor.

loans.use: Purchase new materials and tools for sewing.

loans.name: Tautalalelei

texts.en: Tautalalelei is a thirty-six year old mother of three.  She lives in the small Samoan village of Safaatoa Tai.   She is a very energetic woman who successfully raises her children and runs a plantation where she raises taro, bananas and yams.  The plantation is the family’s main source of food, and is also their only income.  Tautalalelei sells her crop at the local market on Fridays and Saturdays.  From this she clears a profit of about ST 200 a week (USD 80).  This profit is critical to keeping current with her children’s school fees and is thus a major support to ensuring they have a bright future.

loans.use: Buy chemicals, fertilizers and weed killer

loans.name: Uila

texts.en: Uila runs a taro plantation.  Her husband does not have formal wage employment, but he works alongside Uila to make the plantation successful and also does some fishing.  Uila and her husband have two children for whom they are anxious to build a good life and give them a future full of opportunity.  Uila knows that keeping current with the children’s school fees/supplies is critical to their future, and her plantation income is critical in doing so.  Uila has used two previous SPBD loans to develop and upgrade her plantation.  Having repaid these loans in full, Uila is eligible for a third loan, which she will use to build a barrier fence to keep out both neighborhood people and pigs – both have a habit of digging up her taro crop.

loans.use: Build a barrier fence for protection of her plantation.

loans.name: Soo

texts.en: Soo moved to the Samoan village of Samusu to live with her husband’s family.  When deciding how she was going to generate income for her family in this small village, she determined that enough village demand existed to support a simple canteen.  So Soo launched her canteen where she now sells about 150 orders of donuts and chips each week.  This brings in about ST 200 weekly (USD 80) and is a critical supplement to the family finances.  Soo is also very focused on saving some of her income as insurance against future hard times.  She is one of the people in her SPBD Center that consistently contributes to her savings account.

loans.use: Buy ingredients and containers

loans.name: Faalua

texts.en:
Faalua is 28 years old. She is married and has three children – two girls and one boy. In order to support their family, Faalua and her husband farm a small taro plantation. Faalua works the land alongside her husband.

Faalua hauls two to three bags of taro to the village market twice a week. From her crop, she can bring home about ST 200 – 300 (about USD 80 – 120). She is passionate about ensuring that her three children stay in school and have a bright future full of opportunity. It is the sale of their taro crop that enables Faalua and her husband to afford the school fees for the children’s primary school. Knowing that this income is the key to her children’s future, Faalua is anxious to continue investing in and upgrading their taro plantation.

loans.use: Purchase equipment:  knives and tools

loans.name: Lisa

texts.en: Lisa is a young, married mother of two children.  She was once employed in the capital city as a cashier at the pharmacy, but she was forced to resign because she didn’t have any affordable childcare options available for her children while she was at work.  However, her family relied on the income that Lisa brought in, so in order to remain the income earner, she developed a small taro plantation near her house.  By hauling her crop to market twice a week, she can actually earn more than she was able to receive in her weekly wages in town.  So Lisa is anxious to use loan funds to purchase some fertilizers and tools to enhance her crop yield and increase her income further.

loans.use: Purchase fertilizer and tools

loans.name: Maseiga

texts.en: Maseiga is married with four children.  She lives very far from town.  In order to support her family, she weaves mats in the traditional Samoan way.  At one time all Samoan women knew how to weave both the mats used daily in Samoan households as well as the fine mats used on special occasions, such as weddings and funerals and village ceremonies.  Now Maseiga is in the minority.  But she is committed to using her weaving talents to support her family.  She focuses on making the fine mats.  These mats can command high prices because they are very intricate and labor intensive.  It can take up to two or three months to weave just one fine mat.

loans.use: Purchase paints for decorating the mats

loans.name: Faapalagi

texts.en:
Faapalagi is married with nine children.  She lives with her husband, children and her mother in a small house.  She says that raising her children and providing for her family has been a constant struggle.  Faapalagi has used her talent in designing and printing fabrics (by hand) in order to provide for this large family as best she could.  However, it wasn’t until she joined SPBD and had access to credit that she was able to really launch a formal business.  

She has used previous loans to build up her business, and she now fulfills orders not just from local villagers but also from the retail stores in the capital.  She feels confident that she can continue to build up her enterprise and noticeably raise the standard of living of her large family.  She will use additional loan funds to purchase more materials, paints and printing plates.

loans.use: Purchase materials and printing supplies

loans.name: Rosalina

texts.en: Rosalina was from one of the larger towns in Samoa, but she married a man from Samusu village and moved there to be with him.  In their village, her husband runs a small taro plantation and Rosalina says that he works very hard to make the plantation a success.  However, Rosalina joined the SPBD program so that she could find a way to earn additional money, as the income from the plantation cannot fully support her family’s needs.  With an initial SPBD loan, Rosalina launched an ice cream business.  Her main customers are the children from the local primary school, and they have turned into a loyal crowd.  She sells between 60 and 70 ice creams a week bringing in between ST 100 and 150 (about USD 40 – 60) for her family.   Given the nature of her business, Rosalina’s freezer is key to maintaining a steady income.  Rosalina will use a loan to overhaul her freezer and ensure it remains in good condition.

loans.use: Freezer repairs

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Maria is thirty-two years old and has six children.  Due to family circumstances, she never finished her schooling and was for some time unemployed.  When she heard about SPBD, she joined because she felt like this would be a way for her to begin to earn a living and provide for her children.  She used her first and second loans to launch and expand her flea market stall.  She buys merchandise from large companies in the big town and resells to the villagers at the local market, ensuring that even the villagers have access to these products.  Mostly, she sells shoes, perfumes, sunglasses and hair accessories.  Maria is a good businesswoman and has grown her business successfully.  She feels that she can increase her profits further if she can expand her product line yet again.  A loan to Maria will help her do that.  Given Maria’s own experience, she is passionate about ensuring her six children complete their education.

loans.use: Merchandise for re-sale

loans.name: Malia

texts.en: Malia is the Chief of her village’s SPBD Center.  And she is one of SPBD’s best Center Chiefs, as she takes her duties very seriously and ensures that she has collected payments from all of her fellow loan group members prior to an SPBD Manager arriving in the village for the weekly group meeting.  Malia is also a good role model for her Center's group because she runs a successful business weaving and crafting women’s handbags.  She makes a variety of sizes and different types of decoration but all are woven from the leaves of a native Samoan plant, laufala. Maria is a widow, and her husband died a long time ago.  Maria has used her weaving talents for some time now to support herself and put her two daughters through school.  She now weaves and creates about five handbags a week and that brings in about ST 20–30 per week (about USD 8–12).

loans.use: Buy needles, boxes, decorative materials

loans.name: Sauaso

texts.en: Sauaso is a young, active woman.  She is married with two children.  She has a talent for making hand-printed fabrics and using her fabrics for making men’s dress shirts, T-shirts and sarongs (locally referred to as lavalava).  She used an initial loan from SPBD to purchase her sewing machine and printing equipment.  Her business has been very successful, and she was able to pay back this loan in full and on time.  Given her history, Sauaso qualifies for a home improvement loan, and she is seeking loan funds in order to repair the roof and back of her house.  Given that her home doubles as her workshop, this loan will ensure that she can protect her income stream and continue to keep her work safe and dry.  Sauaso’s dream is to be able to build a separate workshop apart from her house; she says that she will work toward this goal with future loans.

loans.use: Home improvements

loans.name: Mele

texts.en:
Mele rents a stall at the main flea market. In her stall she sells handicrafts and jewelry to tourists and locals. She stocks the handicrafts that are handmade by Samoan villagers. Mele readily admits that she enjoys running her own business and being in charge of her family finances.

Mele has a long track record of running her flea market stall successfully. She joined the SPBD program so that she can access the capital necessary to ensure that she can keep a consistent supply of merchandise in her stall at all times. Mele is one of the SPBD members who will use a loan periodically as her business demands, but she usually pays them off more quickly than required.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her flea market stall

loans.name: Vaiolupe

texts.en: Vaiolupe is twenty-one years old and is married with one daughter.  When her daughter was born, she knew that she would need to take it upon herself to support her family financially.  In school, she learned how to print fabrics by hand.  She used this knowledge and an initial SPBD loan to start up her fabric printing business.  Vaiolupe is now seeking a second loan to purchase supplies that will enable her to expand her product line, such as a larger quantity of better quality materials and different types of paints.  She knows that her family will grow, and she wants to take responsibility for ensuring that she can support that growth.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and printing paints

loans.name: Teina

texts.en: Teina is 36 years old and is married with five children.  She runs a successful shop that sells a variety of household and personal care items to the local villagers.  Both Teina and her husband work together to ensure the store is fully stocked and consistently open for business.  With the earnings from their store, they are able to provide decent living conditions for their family and keep their children in school and remain current with the school fees and supplies.  Teina is a long-running member of SPBD.  She is able to use loans to continually work on upgrading and expanding her shop.  She is seeking loan funds in order to finance an inventory purchase whereby she can further expand her product line.

loans.use: Buy merchandise for resale in her shop

loans.name: Tina

texts.en: Tina is 32 years old and has four children.  She was running a coconut tree farm.  She would harvest the coconuts when they were mature enough to drink and haul them to town to sell for locals to enjoy.  (A favorite refreshment or mealtime beverage for Samoans is fresh coconut water, drunk straight from the coconut.)  However, Tina has now mostly left the coconut harvesting and selling to her children.  She now spends most of time practicing the traditional Samoan art of weaving.  She hopes that with the children focusing on the coconut business and with her focusing on the weaving, they can generate enough income to make ends meet.  A loan to Tina would enable her to purchase some weaving tools and supplies to make this second business successful.

loans.use: Tools and supplies for weaving

loans.name: Faalaniga

texts.en: Faalaniga is a 52-year old woman with seven children.  All of her children remain in school.  She is very proud of her ability to provide an education for each of them, and she attributes her ability to do that to her successful weaving business.  And for her weaving talent, she says that she thanks God.  Faalaniga has been an active SPBD member for four years now, and says that it is through consistent access to the micro-loan facilities that she has been able to ensure that she can get enough bulk supply of weaving leaves and decorative materials to be able to guarantee a consistent supply to her customers and the timely fulfillment of orders.  A loan to Faalaniga will help her continue to do what she has already proven she can do:  provide for herself and her children.

loans.use: Weaving leaves and decorative materials

loans.name: Faaupu

texts.en: Faaupu is twenty-nine years old.  She has two children in school.  She is passionate about ensuring that her children have a bright future full of opportunity, and she says that it is for this reason that she joined SPBD to start a small business.  Faaupu wants to make a meaningful contribution to her family finances and hopes that it can substantially raise their standard of living.  She is seeking a loan to help her with her new ice-pop business.  She sells flavored ices in her village and will use loan funds to purchase bulk (and therefore cheaper) supplies of the necessary ingredients.  Faaupu is an ambitious woman, and the goal she is working towards is running a full retail shop in her village.

loans.use: Purchase bulk supplies of sugar, cordial, purified water

loans.name: Fuafua

texts.en: Fuafua is hard-working woman.  She is seventy-four years old, and although she never had a child that was biologically her own, she raised eight adopted children.  She adopted these children from her siblings who could not financially support them.  Fuafua says that with love, it was easy to raise these eight children.  Each of them is now grown and has had the opportunity to move overseas to seek better employment opportunities.  Fuafua is rightfully very proud of the future she was able to provide for them.  She knows her children love her as if she was their biological parent and could help support her, but Fuafua is adamant about remaining financially independent, and she relies on her weaving talent to support herself.  She weaves mats and hand fans in the traditional Samoan way.  She is well known for her craft among the villagers who all come to her to buy the mats they use in their houses and the ubiquitous hand fans that Samoan village women carry.

loans.use: Weaving leaves and decorative materials

loans.name: Naoupu

texts.en: Naoupu is a hardworking, thirty nine year old woman.  She is a married mother of six school-age children.  Naoupu also has seven siblings, and the income she brings in from her ice-pop business not only goes to support her children but in typical Samoan fashion, is shared among her siblings and extended family also.  She has used loans from SPBD to build up her ice-pop business.  She says that she is the top seller of ice-pops in her village, and she attributes this to a unique ingredient that she won’t disclose.  Having fully repaid previous loans, Naoupu is eligible for an additional loan, which she will use both to support her business by purchasing bulk supplies but also to make a payment on her children’s fees.

loans.use: Purchase bulk supplies of sugar, cordials, purified water and pay children’s school fees

loans.name: Aliceann

texts.en: Aliceann L. F. owns a small grocery shop in her village.  Her husband works in one of the supermarkets in town, and their combined income allows them to send their four children to school.  Aliceann set up a shop in her village’s center because that is where the most foot traffic is.  With her strategic location she has strong sales.  With another SPBD loan (Aliceann has a strong history of on-time repayment of past loans), she will purchase bulk goods to re-sell in her store.  Many villagers have irregular access to the large supermarkets in town, and it is stores like Aliceann’s that ensure the rural population can get consistent supplies of food and basic household items.  Aliceann says that she works hard because she dreams of her children being able to live comfortably someday.  Her biggest dream, she says, is to be able to send her children to University

loans.use: Re-stock her shop with goods

loans.name: Uligaui

texts.en: Uligaui is 43 years old.  She is married and has four children, one of whom is handicapped.  Her husband works as a construction worker in the main Samoan town.  Uligaui’s husband’s wages are not enough to support all the family’s expenses and keep all the children in school.  So Uligaui launched a sewing business so that she can be a partner in the family finances and ensure the children have a future full of opportunity.  Uligaui believes that if she had a new sewing machine she would be able to substantially boost per production and revenues, so she has applied for a SPBD loan to help her fund this large purchase and some sewing supplies that will help her make her creations more attractive to potential customers.

loans.use: Purchase new sewing machine and sewing supplies

loans.name: Ana

texts.en: With an initial loan from SPBD, Ana, 25 years old, launched a small business selling ice-pops.  Flavored ices are a favorite treat of the Samoan schoolchildren.  Ana’s business success has helped her support her family, which consists of one child of her own and eight dependents from her extended family.  With the large demand from neighborhood children, Ana can make a clear profit of about USD 20 a day, Monday through Friday.  She uses the money mostly for her son’s educational fees, food for her large household and of course to make her weekly loan repayment.  Her next business idea is to expand her ice-pop business into a full food stall where she can sell a variety of treats and cooked foods.  She will also use her next loan to make some much-needed home repairs.

loans.use: :  building supplies (cement, corrugated iron, timber) and food supplies

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en: Antonia runs a successful village store and food stall.  She stocks basic food and household supplies for her fellow villagers, and she also sells cooked food and bakery items that she makes herself.  Antonia’s family – nine children and her husband – relies on her store and food sales as their sole source of income.  She used an initial loan from SPBD to re-stock her shop.  Having repaid her initial loan in full and on time, she is applying for a second loan.  She will use these loan funds to purchase a gas oven that she can use to do her baking and cooking for her food sales.  A gas oven will replace the slower, more manually intensive, traditional process of using an underground “oven” filled with hot stones.  She is confident that there is enough demand for her products to ensure that she can quickly pay back this new loan.  Her goal is to expand into a full-scale restaurant.  Providing loan funds to Antonia will enable her to take the next steps necessary to reach that goal.

loans.use: Purchase a gas oven

loans.name: Heta

texts.en: Heta is a forty-year old woman with six children.  She and her husband rely solely on their fishing catch to support their large family.  All six children are attending school and keeping current with their school fees is difficult for them.  Heta’s husband does most of the actual fishing, while Heta is responsible for the selling their catch each day to the local villagers.  She is also responsible for managing the family and the business budget.  Heta is seeking a loan so that they can upgrade the equipment they use in hopes of increasing their daily yield.  Heta readily expresses her gratitude for these micro-loan facilities, as she says she is confident that this is a way for her to really do something for her family.

loans.use: :  Fishing lines, nets, gears

loans.name: Penina

texts.en:
Penina and her husband were unemployed and had depended on their relatives for survival.  Their three children went to live with relatives because Penina and her husband had no way of supporting them.  Penina lives in a small Samoan village where there are no opportunities for formal employment.  Thus, Penina joined SPBD.  

She knew that she had to find a way to capitalize on her talents to bring in income for her family.  She decided to start a sewing business, and she used an initial loan from SPBD to purchase a sewing machine.  Penina’s business is going well and loan funds will allow her to purchase fabrics and needed supplies to ensure that she can meet her customers’ demands for consistent, high-quality product.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and sewing supplies

loans.name: Ellsie

texts.en: Ellsie is a mother of two children.  She is twenty-nine years old.  She admits that the income from her business determines whether her children have enough to eat and can stay in school or not and that this creates a lot of pressure for her to be a successful businesswoman.  Ellsie buys handicrafts and clothing handmade by local villagers and resells their products at the larger market in town.  She says that her business is suffering from competition because there are so many nearby stalls that sell similar goods.  Ellsie is thus applying for a loan from SPBD.  Her plan is to use loan funds in order to purchase merchandise that can differentiate her product line from her nearby competitors.  SPBD is confident that loan funds combined with Ellsie’s ingenuity will ensure that the income stream from her stall remains healthy.

loans.use: Purchase merchandise for her flea market stall

loans.name: Kilita

texts.en: Kilita runs a lawn mowing business.  It is very hard work, but she says that it is worth it because of the money she is able to earn.  She says that demand for her services is so high that her major constraint right now is that she only has herself plus one part-time laborer to do the work.  She says that she needs to do two things to grow her business even further:  1) hire another employee; and 2) repair and upgrade her equipment.  Kilita is confident that with another SPBD loan to provide the working capital, she can expand and upgrade enough to meet her community’s high demand.

loans.use: Repair and upgrade mowing equipment

loans.name: Freida Lisa

texts.en: Freida is a 35 year old woman from a small Samoan village.  She is married and has five children.  Her husband works as a taxi driver, but his income is inconsistent and not enough to support their large family.  Frieda is a very talented tailor but lack of finances has kept her from launching a formal business.  Frieda applied for an initial small loan from SPBD that she used to purchase fabric that she then sewed by hand.  Having repaid this initial loan and now confident that there is enough demand for her services, she has applied for a second loan.  These funds will go towards the purchase of a sewing machine and other supplies.  A sewing machine will allow her to speed up her production and fill customer orders much more quickly.  Freida’s goal is to build up a regular customer base and thereby secure a regular and dependable income source for her family.

loans.use: to purchase a sewing machine and fabric

loans.name: Maluai

texts.en: Maluai is a 28 year old mother of three children.  She runs a small grocery shop to support her family.  She started a stall in front of her house where she sold fruits, vegetables and a few basic household items.  However, she found that she was not able to generate enough income to cover her family’s expenses.  When she heard about SPBD from a friend, she joined.  With her loan, she expanded her stall into a proper village store.  This marked a turning point for Malauai and she now is a proud proprietor of a small but successful grocery.  She is applying for additional loan funds in order to further expand her grocery store.

loans.use: to expand and re-stock her shop

loans.name: Juma

texts.en:
J. Juma has been engaged in fabric sales for 5 years. After leaving the secondary school, he could not continue the education. He is married and has five children. He recently married off his elder son. Furthermore, as it should be, he had to provide him a separate apartment. In order to give his children good education – he is trying to create conditions for study.

Having begun his business, he mainly looked to his wife for advice – she is more experienced in fineness of fabric quality and demand – however, in present time, he succeeds in the financial part of his business, and also in market needs.

To increase his income level, he undertakes such actions as purchasing more large consignments from main wholesale providers, though he has not been able to do this before – and he needs a greater assortment. The loan provides opportunities for these actions.

loans.use: Increase of good assortment

loans.name: Lele

texts.en: Lele is a 36 year old mother of six children.  She runs a flea market stall at the main marketplace in town, Savalalo.  There she sells her own sewing creations – Samoan dresses in the popular style (puletasis), t-shirts, and handicrafts that her husband and other villagers make, such as large wooden bowls for mixing kava.  She will use a SPBD loan to purchase a new sewing machine, fabric and handicraft supplies.  Lele says that she is able to make decent money from her flea market stall each week and as a result was able to vastly improve her family’s housing conditions.

loans.use: to purchase a new sewing machine, fabric, and handicraft supplies

loans.name: Gloria

texts.en: Gloria A. is a twenty seven year old mother of two sons.  Both of her sons are attending primary school in the main Samoan town. Gloria’s primary motivation and biggest dream is to be able to keep up with the educational expenses of her children and ensure that they have the chance to go to university someday.  She operates a flea market stall in one of the main markets, where she sells handmade Samoan crafts, jewelry and handbags.  She has used past loans to re-stock her shop and is seeking a new loan to do the same.  Providing Gloria with loan funds will help her achieve her dream of a providing a good education for her sons.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her stall

loans.name: Zulfiniso

texts.en: K. Zulfiniso has worked with the trade sphere more than 13 years. She has secondary education by specialty – salesman, so she does not feel a lack of knowledge and experience in trade activity. Her family consists of her husband and 3 children. Her husband is her partner and companion in business. In plan of everyday provision of family needs, she does not experience any difficulties – as the scope of her business allows her to solve any kind of problem without great effort. But she has another dream – to build a big house with all conveniences and all conditions – which is not easy to make in rural area, and nowadays all her efforts are directed to it. And as constant capital removal can damage her business, she decided to try loans, which helps not only to means and also helps raise the business level to a higher plank.

loans.use: Continuous provision of good turnover

loans.name: Gauula

texts.en: Gauula is 49 years old.  She runs a flea market business selling different varieties of popular Samoan products. Gauula stocks Samoan dresses (puletasis), jewelry, hand-woven handbags and other handmade handicrafts.  Gauula has used SPBD’s microloan facilities to periodically re-stock her stall (she purchases merchandise from village tailors and handicraft artists) and expand her product line.  She is determined to expand her business and is thus seeking loan funds.  Gauula says that she now earns enough money to pay for her children’s school expenses, make her loan repayments and fund small improvements to her family’s home.  This is financial progress that Gauula is rightfully very proud of.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her stall

loans.name: Luaipou

texts.en: Luaipou is 46 years old and lives with her husband and children in the small Samoan village of Seesee.  She is adamant about being self-reliant and so she works long hours on her business everyday except Sunday.  Sunday is the day which she devotes to her church community and family.  She runs a stand where she sells fresh and packaged foods.  In a good week, she can bring in USD 150 from these sales.  Luaipou is a determined woman and is anxious to expand her business and improve her family’s standard of living.  Luaipou has repaid all prior SPBD loans in full. With new loan funds, Luaipou will both purchase more food supplies for her stand to re-sell as well as undertake a home improvement project.

loans.use: Luaipou will purchase packaged snacks, samoan cocoa, ice-pops, potted plants for her store.  The loan will also be used to purchase building supplies for a home improvement project.

loans.name: Norkhol

texts.en:
M. Norkhol has technical secondary education, and for a long time she worked as a medical sister. The time when her husband went in search of a job and did not come back, she had to look after 2 children and parents, who regularly needed medicines, for which certainly their pension was not sufficient. For these reasons, six years ago, she quit her previous work, which did not meet all these needs, and she became engaged in entrepreneurship activity.

In spite of everyday difficulties – she raised her level of business, which now allows her to provide her children an education and her parents a comfortable old age. However, her main intention in future is to build a new house, where all her children can be placed with their own families. Namely this is one main motivation for future development of her own business and transition to another, higher level. Such activities she undertakes with the help of the loan -- increasing the scope and quality of the goods she can hasten the turnover – and decreasing the expenditure on each product item, giving her a better margin of profit, which allows for profit in any situation.

loans.use: Activity extension and increase of turnover

loans.name: Telena

texts.en:
Telena is the President and the Centre Chief of SPBD’s center in the Samoan village of Sagafili Mulifanua. She operates an elei printing (hand-painted fabrics) and sewing business. Telena will create a fabric design, hand paint it, and custom tailor it all according to her customers’ wishes. Her whole family – her four children and their spouses – all participate in the business and help her make the designs and paint the fabrics. She extended her home to include a small shop where she can display her products and consult with her customers. She also hung a sign on the front of this shop to help market her capabilities.

Telena has a long and successful history with SPBD and has used four previous loans to help her grow her now-successful enterprise. With an outstanding record of on-time repayment, she is eligible for future funds, and she will use the opportunity to continue to reinvest in and upgrade her business.

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and paints

loans.name: Misitini

texts.en: Misitini is a 48 years old.  She is widow and has to raise her six children on her own.  She joined the SPBD program in order to help her start her business.  She sells vegetables, plants and cooked foods in front of her house every weekday.  Some of her homemade specialties are pork cakes and pancakes.  On a good day she can earn about USD 20 after all expenses.  She is requesting another loan that will help her both expand her business and help her purchase bulk (and therefore cheaper) supplies as well as to make some repairs to her home.

loans.use: :  cement, timber, flour, sugar, oil, mutton

loans.name: Danya

texts.en: Danya lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. She is single and she lives with her family. She is a traditional embroiderer, and she has good work experience. She took her 2nd cycle group loan and bought all new embroidery materials. Now she wants to take anther loan to expand her business and to find more clients and make a good income to help her family. She is very happy now that she can show her talent.

loans.use: To buy extra embroidery materials

loans.name: Vang

texts.en:
Vang was married before 1975. She is a widow with 5 children; 4 sons and one daughter. Her daughter assists her in weaving silk at home, and one of her sons purchases silk products from villagers in order to sell them wholesale in the market in Phnom Penh city. The oldest son helps her look after cows in the village, and the second son is a construction worker working in Phnom Penh city. The youngest son has been studying to be a monk.

She has borrowed loans from MAXIMA for 3 cycles. The current loan amount is $700. She uses these loans to buy silk materials, sewing thread, and the silk products to sell in the market. She also wants to set up one more loom for her daughter and save some amount to buy a motorbike. She has the ability to repay the loan as she has shown since the first loan.

loans.use: Purchase silk materials, sewing thread, and the silk products for selling; set up another loom; and save to buy a motorbike.

payments.comment:
Dear lender,

Mrs. Vang Neav has enough money to pay off her loan.

Thank you.

loans.name: Shiren Agha

texts.en: Shiren Agha lives in district 17 of Kabul, Afghanistan. He is a carpenter with his own shop. He wants to expand his business so he wants to take an individual loan to buy new machines and enlarge his shop and earn more money because he wants to get married. He wants to work hard to solve his problems and he is very happy that he can expand his business and make a good income. He would like to thank AFSG for helping him.

loans.use: To buy new machines

loans.name: Fieta

texts.en: Mrs. T. is married with two children.  She is 25 years old and never had a job prior to joining SPBD.  When she had children, it was difficult for her and her husband to support their young family.  This prompted her to join the SPBD program in order to start a business and provide for her family’s growing weekly expenses and save for her children’s future education.  After SPBD training, Fieta took out an initial loan to launch a business.  She chose to start a barbeque stand and sell cooked food to passersby in her village.  She says that the business is going well. She is anxious to further invest in it and increase her profits by expanding her supply and product line.  The business is really helping her make things easier for her family.  She hopes that by putting more hard work into her barbeque stand she can ensure that her children can go to good schools.

loans.use: to purchase food in bulk, cooking utensils, containers, and packaging materials

loans.name: Then

texts.en: Mrs. Then S. is 27 years old and the mother of three children who are in school (Mrs. S. is in the middle of this picture carrying a pie). They live in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. To supplement the entire family's expenses and her children's education, she and her husband make and sell pie cakes immediately to the market. They can typically make around $7.50/day in revenue. Besides this kind of business, the couple aims to grow rubber trees from which they can make additional income and increase the family's saving. To do this, Then S. is asking for a $1000 loan to help in purchasing a piece of land to grow her rubber crops.

loans.use: Then would like to purchase a piece of land to grow rubber trees.

loans.name: Uputaua

texts.en: Uputaua is married and has two children.  She lives with her children and husband in a small Samoan village.  She joined SPBD because she is focused on her family’s future and knows that her husband’s income alone cannot provide a future of education and opportunity for their children.  With her first loan from SPBD she set up a flea market business selling shoes, clothes and perfume.  The business income is having a really positive impact on her family and she is anxious to expand the business.  With additional loan funds, she would like to expand the business by selling more merchandise (e.g. personal care items), food and drinks.  She dreams of opening up a full-scale restaurant. Given the success of her initial foray into entrepreneurship, SPBD feels confident that she is capable of realizing her dream.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise in bulk to resell at her flea market stall

loans.name: Folorina

texts.en: Folorina recently finished school.  She is twenty-one years old.  Folorina says that most women in her family support themselves via their own small businesses. Rather than search for a job in town, Folorina was anxious to follow their example and rely on her entrepreneurial spirit to support herself financially.  Folorina joined SPBD in order to get access to capital to launch a business.  She decided to start a flea market stall.  In her stall she sells traditional Samoan handicrafts, t-shirts and clothes that she makes herself.  Folorina is a talented tailor and also knows how to print fabric designs by hand.  With another loan, Folorina will expand her stall and product line to include a larger variety of clothing.  She says that she is very happy with the program and wants to continue using the microloans to expand into a full retail shop.

loans.use: to purchase clothing to sell at her flea market stall

loans.name: Nive

texts.en: Nive is 75 years old.  She has raised eight children.  The main source of income in Nive’s family has always been her vegetable garden.  All of her children were put through school by the produce sales from her garden.  When Nive joined SPBD over a year ago, she had decided it was time to launch a more formal business and hopefully increase her earnings.  She took out an initial loan from SPBD to start a flea market stand.  Now, she sells not only homegrown vegetables but also sells Samoan handicrafts made by local villagers and Samoan cocoa raised by her neighbors.  Nive wants to take out a second loan to buy more goods for her stall as well as to buy seeds and tools for her own garden.  She says that she is very happy with the program and that the loans have helped her create a business that she wouldn’t have been able to otherwise.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her flea market stall (handicrafts, Samoan cocoa, vegetable seeds and gardening tools)

loans.name: Tuanai

texts.en: Tuanai is a very active young lady.  She is committed to the SPBD program and says that she doesn’t think she’ll ever leave the program.  She has taken out four loans from SPBD and has an outstanding repayment record.  With her first loan, she started her business of designing and hand-printing fabrics.  She sold the hand-printed fabrics to her fellow villagers.  With her second and third loan, she expanded the business further.  Lastly, with her fourth loan, she set up a flea market business.  At her stall, she sells her own hand-printed fabrics as well as other villagers’ handicrafts and retail items such as shoes.  Her recent loan request will go towards purchasing more merchandise for her stall as well as making some basic repairs to the house where she lives with her extended family.  Like many Samoans, Tuanai is very close to her extended family. The profits from her hard work are the most consistent source of financial support for her family unit of twenty-two people.

loans.use: to purchase merchandise for her flea market stall and make home repairs

loans.name: Tavakal

texts.en:
R. Tavakal, 58 years old, teacher, graduated High Pedagogical University, married, has three children. He works at the school of the district prison and in his free time he works in own trade market: selling stationary for the school children and goods of first needs. He has been busy with trading goods for 11 years. With this loan he is planning to buy games like checkers, chess, balls, jump ropes, badminton, etc., because during the next two months the demand will increase, since it is summer holidays. In August, prior to new school year, Tavakal will restart selling of stationery to help children get ready for the school year. This loan will help children to avail cheap games during summer time and the parents can save time and money, and buy all goods for the school children on the district market, instead of driving to the capital city, which is located 80 km from the district center.

Tavakal is only one trader who is selling such goods on the district market. He is planning to repay the loan in eight months.

loans.use: to increase the assortment of goods and stationery

loans.name: Identity

texts.en:
This entrepreneur has a small welding shop in Kirkuk. He was married two months ago. His house is rented, as well as his shop. He applied for his first loan from Al-Aman to purchase a new welding machine. He wants to paint his shop and hire two laborers to work with him on the new welding machine. He wants to expand and develop his shop. As he said, "I want to see my shop grow."

Disclaimer: This entrepreneur is from a volatile region where the security situation remains unsettled. Lenders to this business should be aware that this loan may represent a higher risk and accept this additional risk in making their loan.

Note: Personally identifiable attributes of this entrepreneur have been altered to protect him or her (i.e. blacking out portions of the entrepreneur in his/her picture, altering his/her first or last name, etc.).

loans.use: Purchase a new welding machine

loans.name: Hong

texts.en: Mrs. Hong Y. is the mother of seven children and is 40 years old. She lives with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia where they are are farmers. They grow crops such as rice, tomatoes, lettuce, herbs, and other kinds of vegetables on their farm and they make a moderate income of around $3/day. One of her children operates a grocery store, another one works on a farm, and the rest attend school. Mrs. Y. hopes the loan will assist her in purchasing some seeds and insecticides to run her farm, and another part of the money will be to increase some grocery products for her daughter's inventory. In the future, she hopes to purchase as many seeds as she can to grow enough to satisfy all of her clients. She would also like to expand her daughter's grocery store with many kinds of products.

loans.use: Mr.s Yuhen would like to purchase some seeds and insecticides for her crops and to buy some grocery products for her daughter's store.

loans.name: Thuy

texts.en: Miss Thuy is 37 and her husband is 43 years old. They have 5 children between 17 and 2 who are going to school. They don’t have any land for cultivation. Mr Thao, her husband is a mason but he can only find work in the dry season. Miss Thuy sells vegetable and fruits at the small market. Her selling is thus important to increase her family about $1.5/person/month. Their income is $9/person/month. Miss Thuy has already repaid the first loan in time. Now, she wants to borrow a loan of $75 for her selling business.

loans.use: sells vegetable and fruits

loans.name: Boo

texts.en:
Mrs. Boo P. (the woman with the red striped shirt in the photo) is 45 years old and the mother of four children. They live with her husband in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. She is a housewife and is a good cook for her family. Her husband, meanwhile, is a soldier and barely makes enough money to supplement the household. To help this, one of her children operates a hairdressing shop where she makes an average of about $11/day. In order to run this business properly, Mrs. P. is asking for a $1000 loan to purchase some hairdressing tools and other equipment to run her daughter's shop. 
In the future, Mrs. P. needs to either expand or own another hairdressing shop which is bigger than this.

loans.use: Mrs. Phov would like to purchase hairdressing tools for a hair salon shop.

loans.name: Hien

texts.en: Mrs Hien is 53 and her husband 56 years old. Their two children died of accident. Their third son is mentally retarded but he can work to find money for him. Other children are going to school in grade 10 and 7. They don’t have any land for cultivation. Mr Doan, her husband make soya at home and then Mrs Hien sells them at the local market. Average income is low at $6/person/month. Mrs Hien wants to borrow a loan of $ 50 so that she can raise pigs and she will repay loan monthly.

loans.use: sell soya and raise pigs

loans.name: Tuyen

texts.en: Mrs. Tuyen is 43 years old, and her husband is 49 years old. They have two children in school in grades 9 and 6. The family doesn’t own any land for cultivation. They both sell groceries. Mrs. Tuyen sells groceries at the small market. Mr .Thai, her husband, sells groceries from door to door. Their income increased about $1/person/month since they borrowed a loan of $50 from Mekong Plus. Their average income is $10/person/month. Now, she wants to borrow another loan of $50.

loans.use: Buy groceries to sell

loans.name: Khalima

texts.en:
N. Khalima worked as a teacher in secondary school before engaging in entrepreneurship activity - however after the civil war, which made life worse for people – she decided to go to bazaar with the aim of providing her grown up children with necessary things. At present, none of them can provide themselves with necessary things, and she has a task to provide them first with education and then with family and separate dwellings.

So, having such plans for nearest future, she tries to develop her business in such a way to answer the market conditions and population demand, and as the only source of income, can meet all requirements of her family.

loans.use: To increase goods assortment

loans.name: Gulnor

texts.en:
All her life P. Gulnor was a housewife, but in a difficult period, when the country instability began to rise, her husband, who was the bread- winner, became seriously sick and she had to make the living for him and four children. From them until now, their elder son had his own family and recently they have a grandchild.

Thanks to her energy, her business gives a possibility to her family not to think about the problems like education in an institution of higher education and so on. Her main aspiration, which is now realized by her – building a house not only for herself but for her sons, who are not married yet.
